title: 107_hr57
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Elections Review Commission Act" and establishes a commission with specified membership. The Federal Elections Review Commission (referred to as the "Commission") is established to study the Federal electoral process, ensure integrity, and public confidence in Federal elections. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by the President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The House of Representatives appoints three members to the Commission who must have expertise in Federal election laws, the US Constitution, and not be US officers or employees. Efforts are made to ensure members represent diverse regional and political perspectives and provide fresh insights to maintain the integrity and public confidence in the Federal electoral process. The Commission members are appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment for life. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled the same way as the original appointment. The Commission holds its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. A chairperson and vice chairperson are elected from the members, with additional meetings called by the chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for business transactions. The Commission members are appointed for life within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies are filled the same way as the original appointment. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for business transactions, and each member's vote holds equal weight. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with examining the Federal electoral process, making recommendations for its integrity and public confidence. Specific issues include the rationale for the electoral college, voter registration, and ballot access hurdles. The Commission is examining Federal electoral process issues such as ballot access hurdles, ballot design and technology, and election day polling place concerns. The Commission is exploring election day polling place issues, feasibility of multiple day elections, impact of winner-take-all voting, and challenges faced by uniformed services in voting. The Commission is examining election reform options for uniformed services stationed overseas, presidential primary and debate processes, costs of implementing reforms, and the impact on voting speed, accuracy, security, and various demographic groups. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 12 months of its initial meeting, including findings, conclusions, and recommendations for addressing identified problems. Members can also submit additional findings and recommendations. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, they can conduct hearings in various regions of the United States. Commission personnel matters are also addressed. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, gather information, and utilize postal services. In terms of personnel matters, each member is compensated at a rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. The chairperson can appoint staff, request Federal employee details, and approve the employment of an executive director with pay not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its final report. $2,000,000 is authorized for the Commission to carry out the Act.
